I think the Civil War is undeniably bad. In addition to dodecimating (new word?) our male population, it destroyed the wealthy South and left it our poorest region. The barbarous actions of Sherman gave us the staggering poverty you see in the South today, and the civil war undeniably contributed to the arrogant Northern chauvinism that disparages Southerners as hicks and Southern pride as racist.
Furthermore, thanks to chicanery and fraud, the Republicans held the White House for 6 straight elections, creating a single party state post-civil war. Along with Lincoln acting like a dictator, the Republican Party's actions from 1860-1896 leave a bad taste in my mouth.
Additionally, the Civil War didn't end slavery: the 13th Amendment did. And even then, it did little to improve the lives of many blacks, who were still de facto enslaved via sharecropping. In 1872, Republicans won the election because Republican-dominated Reconstruction governments, black voters, and many former Confederates not being allowed to vote gave them the South, and thus the election, even while losing the white vote nationally. In 1877, they agreed to remove the military from the South in return for Democrats recognizing Hayes' victory, which gave the South almost entirely over to Democrats, thus dooming black citizens for the sake of Hayes' election. (I have nothing against Hayes, by the way, he is my favorite president.) The first black senator was from Mississippi, in the 1870s; the next black senator wasn't ected until the 1960s in Massachusetts.
. By the next decade, Republicans were able to recoup their losses in the South via the Western states, so they stopped trying to help the blacks in Southern states. Neither the supposed abolitionists nor the Democrats cared that much about blacks; most abolitionists merely opposed the power amassed by slaveholders.
It wasn't until 1965 that things really improved for the vast majority of blacks. I would have preferred legal slavery to have continued for a few decades before being peacefully extinguished than to have "ended slavery" in a half-assed manner which did not at all help most blacks.
To be fair, John Brown was a terrorist and the Civil War was pretty terrible.
"It's outdated" is really not an argument.
